historicalDescription: This narrow alley in the Castello sestiere was known for its proximity to the Chiesa della Madonna della Fava church. The area was a quiet residential district populated by working-class Venetians.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the nearby church dedicated to the Virgin Mary in Calle de la Madonna. This dock served as a primary entry point for pilgrims visiting the sacred site during the Renaissance period.
This landing was frequented by gold beaters (battiloro) who hammered gold into thin sheets for use in artwork and gilding throughout Venice. Their workshops were located near Calle de la Madonna.

Named for merchants who specialized in importing citrons (cedri) used in religious ceremonies by the Jewish community and for medicinal purposes. The dock was a key arrival point for these exotic fruits.
A dock used primarily for religious processions related to the Madonna worship. Religious relics would arrive here before being taken to the nearby church during feast days.
Named for the guild of candlemakers who supplied the numerous churches in Venice, including the Madonna's shrine in Calle de la Madonna. Beeswax and other materials arrived at this dock.
Used by a religious brotherhood dedicated to the Madonna that maintained the shrines and organized processions in her honor. Their meeting hall was located near this landing.
Named for craftsmen who transported and installed sacred icons, many depicting the Madonna, to churches and private chapels throughout Venice.
Where pilgrims would disembark to bring votive offerings to the Madonna shrine, particularly during times of plague or hardship when Venetians sought divine protection.
Named after the prominent Tiepolo family who had a palazzo near Calle de la Madonna and financially supported the local religious institutions during the Renaissance.
The starting point for religious processions that would wind through the city during feast days related to the Madonna. Decorated boats would dock here before the ceremonies began.
Named for the workshops of ecclesiastical vestment makers whose elaborate creations adorned priests during services at the Madonna shrine and other churches.
Named for the many 'grazie' (miracles or divine favors) attributed to the Madonna in this area. Pilgrims would arrive seeking healing or blessings.

Where craftsmen specialized in creating ex-voto offerings (silver miniatures representing healed body parts) would have their workshops. These were offered to the Madonna by those who believed they were healed by her intercession.
Where choir members would arrive for special services at the Madonna shrine, particularly during important religious festivals when elaborate musical performances were staged.
A secure landing point where religious relics would arrive before being installed in the Madonna shrine or nearby churches. Guarded closely during transport to prevent theft of these precious items.
The primary landing point for pilgrims specifically coming to worship at the Madonna shrine. During certain feast days, thousands would arrive by boat to this particular dock.
Named for the Biblical Annunciation to Mary, this dock was especially active during the feast day of the Annunciation (March 25), which was also the traditional Venetian New Year.
A landing point frequented by the most devout worshippers of the Madonna, and a gathering place for prayer groups before they proceeded to the shrine in Calle de la Madonna.
Where large ceremonial candles were unloaded for use in Madonna processions and ceremonies. These enormous candles were often decorated with gold leaf and carried in religious processions.

Named for the rosary beads used in Marian devotion. Craftsmen making rosaries had workshops nearby, and the dock was a gathering point for rosary prayer groups before proceeding to the Madonna shrine.
Named for the tradition of ceremonially crowning statues of the Madonna. The dock would be elaborately decorated during these special ceremonies that typically occurred once annually.
Used by artisans who crafted elaborate wax figurines and decorations for the Madonna shrine and related religious ceremonies. Wax was an important material in Renaissance Venetian religious practice.

Named for the feast of the Purification of the Virgin (Candlemas), this dock was central to the February 2nd celebrations when candles were blessed and distributed to the faithful who arrived by boat.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after an ancient shrine to the Madonna that predated the larger church nearby, this street was known for housing the oldest Marian icon in the district, brought from Byzantium in the 13th century.

Originally a small canal that was filled in during the 15th century, this street maintained its connection to the Madonna through its name, referring to the Virgin Mary. The area became known for small workshops of religious artisans.
This narrow street led directly to the side entrance of the Madonna shrine and was traditionally home to candlemakers who supplied votives for the faithful visiting the nearby Marian shrine.
Named after a reported miracle in 1487 where a Madonna image under this covered passageway was said to have wept tears. The event attracted pilgrims and led to several documented healings.
Home to several workshops of candlemakers who specialized in elaborate votive candles for the Madonna shrine. These artisans were particularly busy during the Feast of the Annunciation.

This canalside street contained several shops of silversmiths who specialized in creating votive offerings for those seeking the Madonna's intercession, particularly silver hearts, limbs, and small ship models from sailors.
The traditional route of the annual Marian procession that occurred on the Feast of the Assumption (August 15), when the Madonna icon would be carried through the neighborhood with great ceremony.

Named after the Brotherhood of the Madonna, a lay confraternity founded in 1342 dedicated to Marian devotion. They maintained their meeting hall on this street and organized charitable works in the area.
Home to several workshops of artists who specialized in religious iconography, particularly Marian subjects. These botteghe were known for producing small devotional paintings for private homes.
Named for the rosary devotion popular among Venetians who prayed to the Madonna. Rosary makers and sellers of prayer beads traditionally had their shops along this street.
A small courtyard where a hospice for female pilgrims visiting the Madonna shrine was established in the early 16th century, operated by a group of tertiary nuns.
A small side street where flower sellers traditionally gathered to sell blooms for offering at the Madonna shrine, particularly lilies which were associated with the Virgin Mary.
Named after the star symbol often associated with the Madonna (Stella Maris - Star of the Sea). The small square featured a well with a star motif that served the local community.
Named for the angelic figures that surrounded the Madonna in the central altarpiece of the nearby church. Several woodcarvers who specialized in angel figurines had workshops here.

A canalside street where sailors would traditionally come to pray to the Madonna before departing on voyages, as the Virgin was considered the protector of seafarers. Several maritime ex-votos were displayed along the street.

This former canal was filled in during the 16th century and named after the Feast of the Annunciation, which was particularly important in the Madonna district and celebrated with special festivities.
Named after Morosina Morosini, dogaressa of Venice (1595-1605), who was a notable benefactor of the Madonna shrine and financed renovations to the church in the late 16th century.
Named for the dove symbol of the Holy Spirit often depicted in Annunciation scenes with the Madonna. A carved stone dove was visible on the keystone of this covered passageway.
Home to goldsmiths who specialized in religious items, particularly gilded frames for Madonna paintings and jeweled crowns that would be placed on Marian statues during feast days.
Named for the Litany of Loreto, prayers honoring the Madonna that would be sung during processions along this canalside street during Marian feast days.

Named after the traditional blue mantle worn by the Madonna in Venetian religious art. Several fabric dyers specializing in the particular lapis lazuli-derived blue used in religious garments had workshops here.
Home to artisans who created small religious medallions, particularly those bearing the image of the Madonna, which Venetians would wear for protection or carry while traveling.
Named for a small religious school established in 1489 that taught children the prayers and devotions associated with the Madonna cult, as well as basic literacy using religious texts.

A small courtyard where those claiming healing through the Madonna's intercession would leave testimonials and votive offerings. The walls were traditionally covered with small plaques commemorating miracles.
Home to textile artisans who specialized in creating elaborate brocade fabrics used for religious vestments and altar cloths in the Madonna shrine and other Venetian churches.
One of the first streets in the area to be paved with stone (rather than packed earth), as it was the main approach for pilgrims visiting the Madonna shrine from the Grand Canal.
Named for the ornate crown that adorned the Madonna statue in the nearby church. Jewelers who specialized in ecclesiastical metalwork traditionally had workshops along this street.

This former canal was filled in the early 16th century and named after the Feast of the Purification of the Virgin (Candlemas), which was celebrated with special ceremonies in the nearby Madonna shrine.
Home to craftsmen who produced ornate oil lamps that hung before Marian images throughout Venice. Many of these artisans were descended from Byzantine craftsmen who settled in Venice after 1204.
Named after the Barberigo family, notable patrons of the Madonna shrine who financed an elaborate side chapel in the late 15th century decorated with Marian imagery.
Named for the iconography of the Madonna of Seven Sorrows, depicted with seven swords piercing her heart. A small shrine with this image was located at the entrance to this street.
A small square near a convent of nuns dedicated to the Virgin Mary, established in 1472. The nuns were known for their embroidery work on religious vestments.
Named for an ornate column capital featuring the Madonna that was visible at the corner of the street. This 14th-century carving was considered especially fine and was often used as a landmark.
Named for the Feast of the Assumption of Mary, this covered passageway featured a small shrine dedicated to this aspect of Marian devotion and was decorated with appropriate imagery.

Home to scribes and illuminators who produced the elaborate choral books used in Marian services, featuring ornate musical notation and illuminated capitals depicting scenes from the life of the Virgin.
Where skilled embroiderers had their workshops, specializing in elaborate religious vestments and altar cloths featuring Marian imagery for use in the nearby Madonna shrine and other churches.
Named for a guild of merchants who placed themselves under the Madonna's protection. They maintained a small chapel on this street and contributed regularly to the upkeep of the Madonna shrine.
This canalside street was named for the Nativity of the Virgin Mary, a feast celebrated on September 8th. During this feast, the canal would be decorated with floating lanterns.

Named for a purported relic of the Virgin Mary's veil that was brought to Venice after the Fourth Crusade and housed in a reliquary in the Madonna shrine. The street led directly to the side chapel containing this relic.

A former canal filled in during the 16th century, this street became home to painters who specialized in Byzantine-style icons of the Madonna, many of them descendants of Greek artists who fled to Venice after the fall of Constantinople.
Home to bakers who specialized in ritual breads and sweets for Marian feast days. These bakers would produce specially shaped loaves for different celebrations throughout the liturgical calendar.
Named after the Priuli family, prominent Venetian nobles who were major benefactors of the Madonna shrine in the 16th century and maintained their family palazzo nearby.

Where skilled metalworkers specialized in chasing and embossing techniques created ornate silver and gold items for liturgical use in the Madonna shrine, including candlesticks, censers, and reliquaries.
Named for a small convent of nuns devoted to the Immaculate Conception of Mary. These nuns operated a small orphanage for girls and taught them embroidery and lacemaking skills.
Named for the lily, a symbol associated with the Virgin Mary representing purity. Florists who specialized in providing fresh lilies for the Madonna shrine traditionally gathered on this street.
A canalside street where manuscript illuminators had their workshops, specializing in religious texts featuring elaborate depictions of the Madonna and scenes from her life.
Home to metalsmiths who specialized in creating liturgical vessels used in Marian ceremonies, particularly ornate chalices and patens featuring Marian imagery.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Filled Canal of the Little Madonnas
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named for the numerous small street shrines featuring images of the Madonna that lined this former canal after it was filled in during the late 15th century.
Named after the painter Paolo Veronese who created a significant altarpiece for the Madonna shrine in the 1560s. His workshop assistants maintained connections with this area after his death.
Named for the concept of divine graces granted through the Madonna's intercession. Devotees would pass through this covered walkway on their way to pray for special favors at the shrine.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the Hail Holy Queen
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the Marian prayer 'Salve Regina' that would traditionally be sung during processions down this street during major feasts of the Virgin.
Home to artisans who specialized in elaborate wax candles and ex-votos for the Madonna shrine, particularly anatomical wax models offered by those seeking healing.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the School of the Devout
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named for a confraternity of laypeople dedicated to Marian devotion who maintained their meeting hall here and organized processions and charitable works in the Madonna's name.
Named for the ornate processional canopy (baldacchino) used to cover the Madonna statue during religious processions. The canopy would be stored in a special building on this small square.
Home to fabric dyers who specialized in the deep blue color traditionally used for the Madonna's garments in religious art, derived from expensive lapis lazuli pigment.
Named after the Donà family, Venetian nobles who were significant patrons of the Madonna shrine in the 15th century and maintained their family palazzo along this canalside street.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the Mount of Piety
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Where a charitable pawnshop operated under Madonna's patronage, providing low-interest loans to the poor as an alternative to usurious moneylenders. Established in 1509 as a work of mercy.
Named for the Visitation of Mary to Elizabeth, this former canal was filled in during the 16th century. A small shrine depicting this biblical scene was erected at one end of the street.
Home to specialized weavers who created elaborate silk and gold thread textiles for religious vestments used in Marian ceremonies throughout Venice's churches.
Named for the ecclesiastical chapter (governing clergy) of the Madonna shrine who maintained their administrative quarters along this street, one of the first in the area to be paved with stone.
Named for the distinctive bell of the Madonna shrine that would ring to mark Marian feast days. Bell founders traditionally had workshops along this street as well.
A small courtyard where particularly devout followers of the Madonna would gather for special prayers and devotions, particularly during novenas preceding major Marian feast days.
Named for the choir school established in the 15th century to train boys to sing for services at the Madonna shrine. The school was known for its excellent musical education and Marian hymns.
A canalside street where the evening Angelus bells would prompt passing gondoliers to pause and recite the Ave Maria. A small shrine with the prayer's text was mounted on the wall.
Named after the Loredan family who were prominent benefactors of the Madonna shrine and commissioned several artworks for it during the early 16th century.

Named after a reported miracle in 1524 when the canal waters were said to have parted to allow a procession carrying the Madonna statue to pass during a flood. The canal was later filled in during the 17th century.

Named for the annual ceremony of crowning the Madonna statue with an elaborate jeweled crown, which would take place during the Feast of the Assumption. The procession traditionally began on this street.
Named for the lay guardians who maintained continuous prayer before the Madonna shrine. These volunteers would pass through this covered walkway during their rotation changes.
